<table border="0" width="100%"> <tbody> <tr> <td align="center" rowspan="2"> <a href="index.html"><img border="0" alt="Padlock closed" title="Padlock closed" hspace="10" src="PadlockClosed.png" width="77" height="106" align="middle"/></a> </td> <td align="left"> The <a href="https://www.web3d.org/x3d/content/examples/Basic/Security/X3dSecurityReadMe.html" target="_blank">X3D Security Examples</a> (in the <a href="https://www.web3d.org/x3d/content/examples/Basic" target="_blank">X3D Basic Examples Archive</a>) show how to use the <a href="http://www.w3.org/Security" target="_blank">World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) Security Recommendations</a> for <a href="http://www.w3.org/TR/xmldsig-core" target="_blank">XML Signature</a> and <a href="http://www.w3.org/TR/xmlenc-core" target="_blank">XML Encryption</a> with X3D. </td> <td align="left" rowspan="2"> <a href="index.html"><img border="0" alt="Padlock open" title="Padlock open" hspace="10" src="PadlockOpen.png" width="79" height="124" align="left"/></a> </td> </tr> <tr> <td align="left"> Additional examples will be shown here to illustrate various security principles such as obfuscation of 3D geometric models, applying passwords, hidden messages, fine-grained control of model access using LOD and Switch, use of Efficient XML Interchange (EXI) compression, using encryption and authentication in combination with compression, and other techniques. </td> </tr> </tbody> </table>
